awd_abstract_narration:
i. Objective:
The objective of this program is to construct a system-on-a-chip that integrates a digital microcontroller together with fluid handling elements such as valves, pumps, and mixers on a single monolithic device. The key advance will be the development of a digital logic microcontroller that is built entirely out of microfluidic valves and channels rather than electronics. Microfluidic computing obviates the need for transduction between the electrical and fluidic domains, enabling all components to be fabricated in parallel in a single process that is amenable to low-cost manufacturing techniques such as injection molding. Specifically, a finite-state-machine controller will autonomously drive fluid-handling operations such as metering, mixing, and timed incubation, relying simply on a moderate pressure differential for power.

ii. Intellectual Merit
The intellectual merit is the pressing need to reduce the complexity, cost, size, and power consumption of integrated microfluidic systems. This will enable the widespread deployment of lab-on-a-chip systems, transforming the landscape of medical diagnostics as well as laboratory research. While there have been previous examples of microfluidic digital logic, an autonomous microcontroller has yet to be reported, thus this project also represents an important advance in unconventional computing.

iii. Broader Impacts
The broader impacts are the potential for drastically improved access to medical diagnostics and the consequent advances in public health in both developed and developing countries. Furthermore, this program will train scientists at the important interface between computer engineering and life sciences.

por.por_cntn:
While the first computers were mechanical, electronics have since proven to be far superior for information processing. However, for the processing of physical media rather than information, there may still be a role for mechanical computers. In this research program, we developed computers built out of miniaturized pipes and valves that perform calculations with air pressure rather than electrical voltages. These are some of the most capable mechanical computers that have ever been built. More than that, however, the networks of pipes and valves that we use for computing can also be used to direct the flow of different liquids. Thus, our mechanical computers are capable of executing programmed sequences of chemical reactions for use in applications such as medical diagnostics. While miniaturizing and automating laboratory operations on a microchip is not new, the chips have typically required significant external machinery in order to function. In contrast, our technology enables a single microchip to integrate chemical reaction chambers, pumps, and a computer controller. Thus we no longer need all of the external hardware that has typically been required to operate a lab-on-a-chip device, making future systems simpler to operate, cheaper to build, and more convenient to transport.

Over the course of our research program, we first developed pneumatic logic gates and then built simple oscillator circuits to serve as clocks. We also developed methods to describe pneumatic circuits mathematically, which was important for circuit optimization. Next, we built memory circuits and counting circuits. We even devised a way to program circuits by punching holes through a rubber membrane, as well as a pneumatic button to allow user input. We also built circuits for controlling liquid pumping. By combining these building blocks into more complicated circuits, we demonstrated a system for metering different liquids and mixing them together, and later, a system for generating a gradient of different chemical concentrations. We are currently working on an automated system for detection of a cancer biomarker.
